awd_titl_txt: Collaborative research: Exploring the impact of cosmic ray feedback on galaxy evolution
awd_abstract_narration:
Astronomers seek to understand how galaxies formed and evolve.  Vast filaments of matter coalesce into galaxies under gravity.  However, unknown forces from within expel gas in the form of galactic winds.    Ruszkowski and collaborators seek to understand whether this missing force could be provided by cosmic rays.  Using computer simulations, they will study effects of cosmic rays on galactic winds.  They will determine whether cosmic rays contribute sufficient force to these winds to expel matter from galaxies completely.  Finally understanding what powers galactic winds will contribute a major advance.  This study may enable a qualitative leap in our understanding of how galaxies evolve.  Results of these simulations will be used in stunning planetarium animations.  Such visualizations engage the public and inspire young people to study science.

This study will probe a range of spatial scales.  It will include hybrid kinetic simulations of cosmic ray propagation around isolated supernova remnants out to galactic disks and finally to cosmological galaxy formation.  Cosmic-ray transport physics will be simulated from first principles.  Local patches of the interstellar medium will be simulated using adaptive mesh refinement.  These results in turn will be used to develop sub-grid models for galaxy and cosmological formation simulations.  This project will constitute the first large-scale study of galaxy formation to include cosmic-ray transport processes on all spatial scales.  It will yield specific predictions for the properties of cosmic-ray driven galactic winds.

por.por_cntn:
Observations show that energetic cosmic rays produced after supernovae explosions fill the entire space in and around galaxies. Theoretical models show that the cosmic rays can have a profound effect on galaxy evolution by driving outflows of gas. However, the specifics of such effect depend on how efficiently cosmic rays propagate through interstellar medium. In the limit where their propagation is completely suppressed or they propagate too fast, they have no effect on galaxy evolution. Characterization of the cosmic ray propagation is thus a subject of intense current debate and is a major source of uncertainty in galaxy formation modelling. 

In this project we set out to develop new approaches for numerical modelling cosmic rays, especially their propagation, using a series of multi-scale simulations from kinetic, particle level plasma simulations to large-scale subgrid modelling and include calibrated models of cosmic ray injection and propagation in galaxy formation simulations. We explored their effects on driving galactic winds and evolution of galaxies.

One of the main results of this project is realization that plasma Bohm instability suppresses propagation of cosmic rays in the supernova bubbles where they are produced. This was shown using results of plasma simulations and semi-analytic models. 

We implemented such suppression in a subgrid model included in large-scale galaxy formation simulations and found that the suppression of CR diffusion and losses near SF regions leads to a decrease of global star formation rate in the simulated galaxy. Most importantly, we showed suppression of CR propagation near injection regions stabilizes galaxy disk and prevents its fragmentation into massive clumps. Given that such clumps are observed in a fraction of distant galaxies, this project showed that comparisons with such observations have the potential of  testing the theoretical models of CR propagation, dramatically improving our understanding of how cosmic rays propagate in the interstellar medium.
